HOPKINS MEN ENJOY TRAINING
Work Is Strenuous But Food Is Plentiful At Fort Myer—Over Forty
Johns Hopkins Students and
Alumni Attending.

Cheerfulness, coupled with admiration for the efficiency of their
superiors, was the keynote of the
expressions of opinion of the
Johns Hopkins men at Fort Myer
after the first strenuous week of
training. There are well over 40
Hopkins men, undergraduates and
graduates of from a few months
to several years standing, and all
of those interviewed by a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER on
Sunday expressed themselves as
"well fed, well clothed, well officered and well satisfied."
The future officers, numbering
about 2,500 and divided into 15
companies are housed in many
long, shed-like barracks at one
side of the big Fort Myer drillfield. Tiers of narrow doublebuilding.
decker bunks fill each'
Each company is in charge of an
officer of the regular army, but
all below him are, as far as any
permanent rank is concerned, entirely equal.
For the first week, those having
considerable previous experience
held the -positions of minor officers, but in the future a changeabout system,, by which each man
in the company has his turn as an
officer, will be in force.
Former Captains Thompson and
Darley of Hopkins served as sergeants for the whole of last week,
but Captain ChesleY and the other
former Hopkins officers acted as
privates..
Immediately upon arrival at
camp last Monday, May 14, the
men were lined up and innoculated for typhoid and smallpox.
This took up the whole of the first
day. On Tuesday the work began,
lightened slightly at first to allow
the men to become acclimated.
The following is the daily routine:
5.20 A. M.—Reveille.
5.30 A. M.—Roll call.
6.15 A. M.—Mess.
8-12 A. M.—Drill.
12.15 P. M.—Mess.
2-5 P. M.—Drill.
5.45 P. M.—Assembly.
6.00 P. M.—Retreat.
6.15 P. M.—Mess.
7.30-9.30 P. M.—School.
9.45 P. M.—Taps.
The few short gaps in the program are fully taken up in such
duties as caring for equipment
and in study. In the latter the
men work together, comparing
notes, correcting each other's
faults. A general air of mutual
helpfulness, of working together

FACULTY VOTES FOR INTENSIFIED TRAINING
Daily Drills to Be Held for Remainder of Term—Final Examinations
to Be Suspended in Order to Allow Training to Go
on Uninterrupted—One "Cut" at Drill
Will Cancel Privilege.
It has been decided by the University faculty that military training is the most important function of the undergraduate department
for the remainder of the year, and that, in view of this consideration
and in view of the fact that drills would have to be immediately done
away with if final examinations were to be held, the examinations are
to be suspended, on condition that every man in the Reserve Officers'
Training Corps attends drill with absolute regularity.
If any member of the corps fails to report at a single drill, he
will be obliged to take his examinations. Classes will continue regularly through June 1, the term marks not being turned in until after
that date. Any man who fails in this mark will be allowed to take
the examinations.
Commencing this week, drills will be held for two hours daily,
with four hours on Saturday.
The faculty has also decided that no more men are to be excused
from college to work upon farms, or for any other purpose, unless
they take the final examinations, paying the five dollar fee incumbent upon such action.
The action taken by the faculty
was not because of any question
of fairness in excusing men for
farm work and other federal service, and requiring those who remained to take final examinations,
but was taken only because of the
necessity of cutting down drills
should examinations be held.
The agitation started when
Battery A men were exempted
from classes and examinations
last week. A thorough discussion
of the situation was held on last
Friday between the Student Council and two of the faculty advisers
to that organization, Dean Brush
and Dr. French. The outcome was
that the case should be put before
the faculty yesterday at 12.45.
At this meeting Dr. French presented the grounds of the students
for the cancelling of final examinations. Since the battalion is to
be inspected on May 30 and graded according to the excellence of
its showing, and since the present
system of drilling would be inadequate for sufficient preparation in
view of allowances being made for
preparation for examinations, the
faculty voted that for the sake of
military instruction, examinations
should be suspended.
This means that those enrolled
in the battalion will have to attend drills daily from 4 to 6
o'clock, with the exception of Saturday, when the time will be from
2 to 6 o'clock. Should anyone
miss a drill, unless he is excused,
by Lieutenant Elliott, and only
extraordinary excuses will be accepted, he will have to take the
examinations. This rule, Dean
Brush has announced, is to be very
strictly enforced.
Classroom work will continue
as usual through June 1, and

quizzes may be held at the discretion of the instructor.
If the instructor informs a student that he will be conditioned in
any subject on his term's work,
the student may take an examination at a time to be set by the
instructor. This question is to be
settled as the instructor sees fit,
and if he deems it advisable other
ways to remove failures may be
taken.
The motion not to interrupt the
training was made by Dr. Buchner, and after being amended by
others was passed, although not
unanimously.
The faculty was united in the
conclusion that no student should
be permitted to leave before June
1 without taking his final examinations and paying the $5 fee entailed in undergoing examinations
at other than the specified times.
Elections for representatives to
the Student Council were held
last week in class meetings. E.
Jarrett, W. H. Swartz and A. M.
Wolfe were chosen senior delegates, D. W. Burbage and A. L.
Hamburger junior delegates, and
G. S. Cattanack the sophomore
representative. At the meeting
Friday, Jarrett was elected president, and Burbage secretary and
treasurer.
A course for freshmen called
"How to Study" has been instituted at De Pauw University.
A marked improvement in the
scholarship of the class has been
noted.—Ex.
Two students in the University
of Cincinnati law school work as
pallbearers in order to get funds
to pay their college expenses.

FULL QUOTA FOR UNIT ENROLLED
38 Hopkins Men Have Signed Up for
Ambulance Unit—Orders at Any
Moment—Men Will Train
Near Philadelphia.

In all probability the Hopkins
unit of the Medical Reserve Corps
will be formed before June, as
over thirty-eight men have volunteered. When this urgent call for
ambulance service in France was
put before the students by Dr.
Hulburt, members of the faculty,
graduate students, prominent undergraduate leaders and many
others gave their names to him
without hestitation.
Dr. Hulburt has since communicated with the headquarters of
the Intercollegiate Intelligence
Bureau in Washington, from
which the assignment of the unit
came, and is expecting definite information at any moment as to
immediate procedure.
Though
the desired number is thirty-six,
he hopes to enroll at least six
more in order to be assured of the
full quf,ta in case some should be
disqualified.
After the unit is completed, it
will be sent to camp near Philadelphia. After a short period of
training there, it will be sent to
ance.
The members of the teaching
staff who have enrolled are: Mr.
A. L. Hammond, of the English
department, and Mr. F. C. Tarr,
an instructor in the summer
school.

It is announced that the Hullabaloo will be released for distribution on or about May 28, and all
subscribers who have not paid for
their copy are urged to do so at
once. All men who intend to leave
for military or other purposes will
kindly give their names and prospective addresses to N. L. Owings,
'17, in order to enable him to forward the book in due time after
publication.
Harry L. Straus, editor of the
Hullabaloo, has accepted a position as mechanical engineer with
the Cutler - Hammer Company,
and is engaged in making control
apparatus for submarines. He
was to have attended the Fort
Myer camp, but undertook the
position on the advice of army
officials at Fort Myer, who said
he would be rendering more service to the government in such
specialized employment.

Daily Drills to Be Held for Remainder of Term—Final Examinations
to Be Suspended in Order to Allow Training to Go
on Uninterrupted—One "Cut" at Drill
Will Cancel Privilege.
It has been decided by the University faculty that military training is the most important function of the undergraduate department
for the remainder of the year, and that, in view of this consideration
and in view of the fact that drills would have to be immediately done
away with if final examinations were to be held, the examinations are
to be suspended, on condition that every man in the Reserve Officers'
Training Corps attends drill with absolute regularity.
If any member of the corps fails to report at a single drill, he
will be obliged to take his examinations. Classes will continue regularly through June 1, the term marks not being turned in until after
that date. Any man who fails in this mark will be allowed to take
the examinations.
Commencing this week, drills will be held for two hours daily,
with four hours on Saturday.
The faculty has also decided that no more men are to be excused
from college to work upon farms, or for any other purpose, unless
they take the final examinations, paying the five dollar fee incumbent upon such action.
The action taken by the faculty
was not because of any question
of fairness in excusing men for
farm work and other federal service, and requiring those who remained to take final examinations,
but was taken only because of the
necessity of cutting down drills
should examinations be held.
The agitation started when
Battery A men were exempted
from classes and examinations
last week. A thorough discussion
of the situation was held on last
Friday between the Student Council and two of the faculty advisers
to that organization, Dean Brush
and Dr. French. The outcome was
that the case should be put before

its showing, and since the present

faculty voted that for the sake of

miss a drill, unless he is excused,
by Lieutenant Elliott, and only

Brush has announced, is to be very
strictly enforced.

settled as the instructor sees fit,
and if he deems it advisable other
ways to remove failures may be
taken.

training was made by Dr. Buchner, and after being amended by

unanimously.

conclusion that no student should
